questions.text: The SA Node acts as the pacemaker of the heart because, it ____.
questions.solution: The SA node acts as the pacemaker of the heart as it generates impulses at the highest rate (60-100/min), compared to AV node (40-60/min) and Purkinje fibres (15-40). The impulses generated by SA node are conducted through AV node and purkinje fibres repetedly that it will prevent AV node or Purkinje fibres reach their own thresholds for self-excitation.

questions.text: In which of the following the conduction velocity is least?
questions.solution:
The conduction velocity is least in AV node.

The slow conduction in the AV node is caused mainly by diminished numbers of gap junctions between successive cells in the conducting pathways.

questions.text: The velocity of conduction of impulse is maximum in____.
questions.solution:
The velocity of conduction of impulse is maximum in Purkinje fibers.

Purkinje fibers have the maximum number of gap junctions hence the maximum conduction velocity (4m/s).

questions.text: The AV nodal delay is ___(seconds).
questions.solution:
The AV nodal delay is 0.1 second.

The slow conduction is caused mainly by diminished numbers of gap junctions between successive cells in the conducting pathways.It ensures that the atria have ejected their blood into the ventricles first before the ventricles contract.

questions.text: If the SA node discharges at 0.00 sec, when will the action potential normally arrive at the epicardial surface at the base of the left ventricle?
questions.solution:
The duration of action potential to arrive at the epicardial surface at the base of the left ventricle is 0.22sec.

Impulse initiated from SA node at 0.00s

                       ↓

Impulse reaches AV node at 0.03s

                       ↓

Delay of impulse at AV node by 0.13s resulting in a total time of 0.16s (0.03+0.13) to reach the beginning of Purkinje fibres

                       ↓

Impulse reaches base of Purkinje fibres by 0.03s resulting in a total of time of 0.19s (0.16+0.0.3) to reach the endocardial surface of the base of the ventricle

                       ↓

Impulse travels from endocardial to epicardial surface in 0.03s (due to arrangement of myocardial fibres)

                       ↓

Hence, a total time of 0.22s (0.19+0.03) is taken for the impulse to travel from SA node to epicardial surface of the base of ventricles

questions.text: The order of depolarization after stimulation of Purkinje fibers is:
questions.solution:
The order of depolarization is from septum → endocardium→ epicardium.

The spread of Cardiac Excitation:

Atrial depolarization is initiated from SA node spreads radially through atria, then converges on the AV node. A delay of about 0.1s (AV nodal delay) occurs before excitation spreads to the ventricles.
Ventricular depolarization starts at the left side of the interventricular septum and moves first to the right across the midportion of the septum. It moves along the ventricular walls to the AV groove, proceeding from the endocardial to the epicardial surface.

questions.text: Phases of the ventricular muscle action potential are shown below. At which phase of the below image, the action potential is most dependant on sodium permeability?
questions.solution:
The action potential is most dependant on sodium permeability in phase 0. 

Action potential of myocardium:

  • Phase 0: Depolarisation: Influx of Na+ into myocyte.
  • Phase 1: Early repolarization: Efflux of K+ from myocyte.
  • Phase 2: Plateau: Ca2+ enters myocardial cells via voltage regulated L-type Ca2+ channels.
  • Phase 3: Repolarisation: Efflux of K+.
  • Phase 4: Restoration of RMP: Restoration of Na+ and K+ by Na-K ATPase.

questions.text: Plateau phase of ventricular muscle is due to opening of :
questions.solution:
Plateau phase of ventricular muscle is due to opening of Ca channel.

Action potential of myocardium:

  • Phase 0: Depolarisation: Influx of Na+ into myocyte.
  • Phase 1: Early repolarization: Efflux of K+ from myocyte.
  • Phase 2: Plateau: Ca2+ enters myocardial cells via voltage regulated L-type Ca2+ channels.
  • Phase 3: Repolarisation: Efflux of K+.
  • Phase 4: Restoration of RMP: Restoration of Na+ and K+ by Na-K ATPase.

questions.text: Repolarization of cardiac muscle  proceeds from:
questions.solution:
Repolarization of cardiac muscle proceeds from epicardium to endocardium.
 
Depolarisation proceeds from endocardium to epicardium in an intact cardiac muscle.

questions.text: Phase 0 of pacemaker potential is initiated by:

choices.text: Opening of voltage gated Ca2+ channel
Inactivation of voltage gated Ca2+ channel
Inactivation of voltage gated Na+ channel

questions.solution:
Phase 0 of pacemaker potential is initiated by opening of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels.

The pacemaker potential consists of:

  • Phase 0 - this is upstroke seen due to the opening of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels. This causes an influx of calcium leading to the upstroke.
  • Phase 3 - This is followed by inactivation of the calcium channels and simultaneous activation of K+ channels. This leads to efflux of K+ bringing about repolarization.
  • Phase 4- As the K+ efflux declines, a channel permeable to both Na+ and K+ opens leading to an influx of both Na+ and K+. This is the If channel. This is responsible for slow spontaneous diastolic depolarization. This accounts for the automaticity of SA and AV node.

The slope of Phase 4 in the SA node determines the heart rate.

Note: Fast voltage-gated Na+ channels seen in myocyte potential are permanently inactivated because of the less negative resting potential of the pacemaker cells.

questions.text: You are researching the benefits of vagus nerve stimulation as a potential treatment for epilepsy. Which of the following parameters can be increased due to vagal stimulation?
questions.solution: Vagal stimulation can cause an increase in the R-R interval in the ECG as it decreases heart rate.

questions.text: In recording Lead I, the right arm is negative electrode and the positive electrode is
questions.solution:
In recording Lead I, the right arm is negative electrode and the positive electrode is left arm.

 Bipolar Limb leads for ECG recording

Lead type

Negative input (-)

Lead I

LA

RA

Lead II

LL

RA

Lead III

LL

LA
  • LA → left arm
  • RA →right arm
  • LL→ left foot

questions.text: Einthoven law states that
questions.solution:
Einthoven's law states Lead I + Lead III = Lead II.

Einthoven's triangle is an imaginary formation of three limb leads in a triangle used in electrocardiography.

questions.text: In Einthoven’s triangle, what is the value of lead III when lead I = 1mV and lead II = 2mV ?
questions.solution:
According to Einthoven's law, 

Lead I + Lead III=Lead II.

Lead III = Lead II – Lead I = (2-1) =1 mV.

questions.text: In a standard ECG, an augmented limb lead measures the electrical potential difference between:
questions.solution:
In a standard ECG, an augmented lead measures the electrical potential difference between one limb and the other two limbs. aVR, aVL, aVF are the augmented  limb leads.

Related Pearl: Augmented Unipolar Limb Leads

Lead type

Positive input

Negative input

aVR

Right arm (VR)

Mean of left arm (VL) and left foot (VF) potential

aVL

Left arm (VL)

Mean of right arm (VR) and left foot (VF) potential

aVF

Left foot (VF)

Mean of right arm (VR) and left arm (VL) potential

questions.text: Which part of the ECG corresponds to ventricular repolarization?
questions.solution:
The part of the ECG that corresponds to ventricular repolarization is T wave.

ECG waves

Events in the heart

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: The PR interval indicates ____.
questions.solution:
The PR interval indicates atrial depolarisation(P wave) and AV node conduction time(PR segment).

PR interval is the time between the beginning of the P wave and the beginning of the QRS complex. It is the interval between the beginning of electrical excitation of the atria and the beginning of excitation of the ventricles. Normal duration is 0.12-0.20s.

 

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

ST segment

questions.text: The P wave is absent in ___.
questions.solution:
The P wave is absent in atrial fibrillation.

In atrial fibrillation, numerous small depolarization waves spread in all directions through the atria. The waves are weak and many of them are of opposite polarity at any given time, they almost electrically neutralize one another. Therefore, P waves are absent from ECG in atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: The normal mean QRS axis lies between ______
questions.solution:
The normal mean QRS axis lies between –30° and +110°.

The QRS axis represents the major vector of ventricular activation, which is the overall direction of electrical activity.

questions.text: The sympathetic innervation to AV node is by___.
questions.solution:
The sympathetic innervation to AV node is by Left stellate ganglion.

Innervation of SA Node and AV Node:

The SA node develops from structures on the right side of the embryo and the AV node from structures on the left.Therefore -

ANS

SA node

AV node

Parasympathetic

Right vagus

Left vagus

Sympathetic

Right stellate ganglion

Left stellate ganglion

questions.text: You are following up with a patient on a sympathomimetic drug. Which of the following effects is unlikely to be due to sympathetic stimulation?
questions.solution:
Sympathetic stimulation causes faster conduction, therefore decreased refractory period.

Effects of sympathetic stimulation:

  • Chronotropic- It increases the rate of sinus nodal discharge.
  • Dromotropic- It increases the rate of conduction.
  • Bathmotropic- It increases the level of excitability in all portions of the heart. 
  • Inotropic- It increases the force of contraction of all the cardiac musculature.

questions.text: The AH interval on His Bundle Electrocardiogram (HBE) corresponds to the conduction of _____ on ECG.

choices.text: From AV node to bundle of His

questions.solution:
The AH interval corresponds to conduction from AV node to bundle of His on an ECG.

His bundle electrogram (HBE)

The record of the electrical activity obtained with the catheter passed through a vein to the right side of the heart and placed close to the tricuspid valve is HBE.

It shows 3 deflections as shown in the figure:

 

His bundle waves

Description

A

Denotes AV node activation

H

Denotes His bundle activation

V

Denotes ventricular depolarization 

 

With HBE and standard ECG leads, 3 intervals can be timed accurately

 

Interval

Recording

Corresponding event

PA interval

Time from the first appearance of atrial depolarization to the A wave in HBE

Conduction time from SA node to AV node

AH interval

From A wave to start of H spike

AV nodal conduction time

HV interval

Time from start of H spike to start of QRS deflection in ECG

Conduction in Bundle of His and bundle branches
